newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL overnight interbank rate holds above 6.0 pct.
newsitem.headline: KL overnight interbank rate holds above 6.0 pct.

text.p: The overnight interbank rate was again kept between 6.5 and 7.0 percent on Monday as lenders maintained their rates despite a liquid market, dealers said.
The rate closed at 6.70/80 percent against 6.50 on Friday.
"The overnight is holding very well despite rising liquidity," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank.
He said with no new issue or maturity of Bank Negara bills this week, interbank rates were expected to stay around current levels.
Market liquidity had improved further following maturities of a 420-million ringgit long term government bond issue and a 500-million ringgit Bank Negara bills issue last week.
Dealers said that even though there was excess liquidity in the market, lenders were wary of offering lower as rumours of a new bonds issue remained rife in view of more bonds maturing this month.
Long-term government bonds worth 900 million ringgit will mature on May 15.
"If the issue is not rolled over, rates may come off again," said another dealer.
Earlier, interbank rates were mostly unchanged.
One-week money was at 6.50/90 percent against 6.5/7.0 on Friday and three-week was unchanged at 7.10/20 percent.
One-month money at 7.25/30 percent, three-month at 7.30/35 and six-month at 7.35/40, were all unchanged.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were also traded unchanged.
At 0900 GMT, the benchmark three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was unchanged at 92.67, or an implied yield of 7.33 percent.
December was at 92.66, or 7.34 percent, and March 1998 at 92.58, or 7.42 percent, both unchanged.
